content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to change procedures for court jurisdiction in various subsections. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to change procedures for court jurisdiction in various subsections by specifying the courts with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code specifies the courts with jurisdiction over the offense being investigated, including federal courts and state courts with general criminal jurisdiction. It also outlines the criteria for courts that have jurisdiction, such as being in the district where the provider of a communication service is located, or acting on a foreign assistance request. Additionally, a new section is added for foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code allows Federal judges to issue orders to assist foreign authorities in criminal investigations and prosecutions, including search warrants and orders for electronic communications. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code allows Federal judges to issue orders, such as search warrants, for assisting foreign authorities in criminal investigations. This includes warrants for electronic communications, orders for testimony or statements, and the production of documents. Additionally, Federal judges can appoint a person to oversee the taking of testimony or the production of documents in response to a request from a foreign authority. In response to an application for execution of a request from a foreign authority, a Federal judge may appoint a person to direct the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents. The appointed person has the authority to issue orders for appearance, administer oaths, and receive testimony or statements and documents. For search warrants, the application must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A search warrant from a foreign authority must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A Federal judge can issue a search warrant only if the foreign offense would be punishable by imprisonment for more than one year in the United States.
